author: gilvania
title: Cardano to Portuguese-speak Africa
description: Portuguese is a popular language in Africa, even so there is a lack of educational content on Blockchain and Cardano in Portuguese.

f6_assessments.q0: The 'Grow Africa, Grow Cardano' challenge basically aims at increasing Cardano awareness and knowledge across the African continent. Indigenes of Africa speak more languages that English which is poplar in the cardano community. However, many materials are only available in English, which inherently eliminates non-English speaking population. To raise awareness and make Cardano the blockchain of choice in Africa by 2023, education and resources must be available in most of Africa's major languages, including Portuguese. This project aims to work with a catalyst school to translate and educate people about Cardano and other catalyst materials in Portuguese. The proposal intends to make the Cardano community more accessible to students and tech enthusiasts in Cape Verde, Equatorial Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Sao Tome & Principe, Angola, and Mozambique by giving a free online course on Blockchain and Cardano in Portuguese. Hence, this proposal effectively addresses the challenge

However, this proposal is highly likely to be implemented.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal provides sufficient information to audit and evaluate the project's progress toward its stated goals, given on the well-developed material from the impact and feasibility categories, as well as the metrics and KPIs the proposers will use to measure the project's success. This proposal can be audited successfully.

f6_assessments.q0: The submitter wants to provide educational content in Portuguese about blockchain and Cardano. The advantage is that the poor population can also participate because it is free. This project appeals to a target group of 232 million Portuguese-speaking people. This project can therefore add value to Cardano. The goal is to put 10 hours of content about Cardano and blockchain technology on an online platform (Translated into Portuguese). The online courses can make students want to continue working with Cardano. No risks are included in the proposal. This project offers a collective engagement with Cardano and blockchain. The future of this project is to involve the Portuguese speaking people from Africa in future activities in the blockchain.
f6_assessments.q1: Gilvania Vilela is a senior lecturer at a Brazilian engineering college. She has experience drafting STEM courses. The submitter is in contact with other professors to collaborate on this project. The names are not disclosed in the proposal. The advantage is also that this project has already been approved in Fund7, but with Brazilian students as the target group. There is a plan of 3 months to complete everything. It's good that the course content is already displayed. I would still add the NFTs section to the syllabus. Each month there are clear objectives that must be achieved with corresponding budgets. The plan offers a realistic time schedule in which the activities that must be completed per month are stated. It is good that at the end of the project a report is drawn up on the proposed project with analysis of the results to open clear future perspectives. The submitter assumes that there are few risks to successful implementation of the project.
f6_assessments.q2: A roadmap has been included in which clear KPIs have been drawn up per month for the interim evaluation of the project. The development of the project is also measured by well-chosen KPIs (number of students, website activity, number of visualisations, video lessons,..). By including these KPIs, it can be determined whether this project is successful. The project will be successful if it can offer 10 hours of video lessons in Portuguese about Cardano and blockchain. There will be a report at the end of the project that will reflect the impact of the video lessons. This allows them to see if there is more involvement with the Cardano community. This proposal certainly offers a solution to the language problem for the Portuguese-speaking population in Africa. By offering the video lessons in their own language, the step to get to know the cardno network will be much smaller.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal addresses the catalyst funding challenge by providing a tool (a course in a new language) to enhance blockchain education (Cardano) in a young market (Africa). In my opinion, this solution would very much meet the challenge, especially since a rough estimate has it that there are about 14 million people who use Portuguese as their sole mother tongue across Africa, but depending on the criteria applied, the number might be considerably higher, since many Africans speak Portuguese as a second language. With Africa has become a very potential market, having a course in Portuguese definitely is a huge push for Cardano to get closer to Africans. The proposer has presented and articulated their idea very forward. We can all see what they are aiming for and it’s 100% doable. If the goal of this proposal is met, it will allow a lot of Portuguese speakers have more opportunities to learn about Cardano and also it will help boosting the Cardano blockchain’s influence in African market. Overall, I believe that this proposal will address the questions posed in this fund 8 challenge and improve upon the catalyst funding mechanism.

The team has outlined all the tasks and milestone quite detailed. However, the roadmap has not been presented very clearly here. I think all the milestones should be assigned with specific deadline that spans in the 3 month plan. Alongside with that, the budget breakdown should follow the roadmap closely to justify the requested funding amount. But overall, all the works are listed fairly and if they are done properly, this project will certainly be a success.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal presents a reasonable amount of audibility that the public can measure performance against. The team has provided a list of key metrics, including number of students attending the course, website activity, student’s feedbacks and so on. There are very clear and measurable deliverables. I would have preferred if the team had made a KPI by timeframe so that we can see the development of the project and we would know where the project aims to be and what would be needed for it to be there. In this way, we would be able to follow the intended progress step by step under any circumstances. One more thing that, this type of project will rely a lot on the feedback they get from the students and the community, which implies the motive of having high levels of transparency. Overall, I agree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals

Amazing proposal. Bringing the blockchain world to Portuguese speakers in Africa is the same as to bring it to, roughly, 14M people. 
However, there are some points that I should add in the risk management:
1)	Marketing: Since this is a new world and probably there are lots of people who are unaware of it (and therefore the search engine never shows this kind of content), it must be allocated here. That said, it’s mandatory a strong marketing strategy. And since you’re looking for people who are strong in maths, maybe consider to contact some universities or some student group (like in Brazil we have the ‘diretorios academicos).
2)	Internet: I’ve read a lot in the Catalyst proposals that there are several areas in Africa which the internet is very poor. Therefore, taking it into account when sharing the content might be interesting, providing more than one media (video, PDF, etc). Creating more than one access method to allow as many people as possible.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea is good and aligned with challenge, potentially addressing challenges kpis as "Number of new African projects seeded in 2022", "Number of African developers onboarded in 2022" and "Local impact (measurable through user activity and reach)".
I liked the syllabus is already pre-defined and clearly demonstrated here and it seems very complete. It also good to know that Q&A is taken into account. If well done, this will help the engagement of the community.

It would be imporant, however, to have stated in the proposal an aproximate number of how many people in Africa speak portuguese. It is mentioned the countries who does but some numbers could be provided to fully assess proposal potential impact. Another imporant data would be the percentage of these population with internet access in Africa, as it is the continent with most limited access to it and the course will be online. For instance, according to statisctics from the World Bank (IBRD), only 36% of people in Angola use internet (source: shorturl.at/crEG2), which could limit the goal of this proposal.
In addition, I wonder if uploading content in an existing course platform was considered. I know it could raise costs a bit, but using an existing platform could save proposers time and help people finding the course, as these platform already have subscribers.

Moreover, countries in Africa have different cultures and, as I understood, proposers are brazillian. Even though the language is the same, it would be imporant to know how overcome distance and culture barries to better communicate with people there and make them engage. This would be a risk that is essential to mitigate. In the same sense, the communication/advertise plan could be better ellaborated here, also including who is really their target audience (STEM students? people who work in tech companies? recenty graduated people?).

Last, I'd also include here in the proposal how this course would differentiate from other courses already available in portuguese in this subject. Maybe having one specially developed for Africa helps, but it would be imporant to know what is included in this special developement that others dont have. This would help to make the value proposition more appealing. If nothing changes, maybe it could be considered to take an already existing course and just advertise in Africa.
